>>9621925
>It can take on a physical form, manifesting as weapons, armor, or sentient beings. The Maverick Virus behaves like an actual virus, spreading through physical space.
The Maverick Virus mutated from the Wily Virus, which was based on the Evil Energy that Wily found in Megaman 8.
According to Duo in MM8, the Evil Energy is actually a sapient alien substance that absorbs evil within robots minds and then multiplies as to infect more robots. Dr. Light found out that performing a full analysis of it was impossible (much like Zero's system). An entity made out of pure energy is an interesting concept since it can be a power source, be translated into electrical signals (and be transmitted as a virus) and even be converted into mass. Due to this method of replication, the original source can only be harnessed by beings of pure evil. The Wily virus made from it probably works in the same manner, "absorbing" Zero's destructive programming when he fought Sigma and had the migraines, and then spreading to Sigma and the rest of the reploids. Only someone who's pure evil could have it in their system and not die from it (like Wily in robot form).

That's why the Maverick Virus is so unorthodox and can do shit normal computer viruses can't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9621756
>It got really stale after a while and my dad who was 7 at the time was too old for a lot of the overlay games
The overlay games were just a flop in general. There's a reason Magnavox' next console, the Odyssey 100, was just a slightly improved version of the original Odyssey (the ball would now bounce back if it hit the top or bottom of the screen) with no overlays or game cards to change the behavior of the ball and paddles - pretty much all Odyssey owners just played the table tennis "Pong" game and ignored all the other games that involved overlays and shit, so they could massively reduce cost by just leaving all that crap out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622512
Yeah, the original Odyssey was less "video game" and more like a box of board games with the Odyssey itself as the central component they were all designed around. It was after that they were able to zero in on what was actually fun about the thing and start building on that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622572
It took a while, really. Here's the Odyssey 100 in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZWPt8XHRUak

>still has the same general button setup as the Odyssey, with one dial for controlling vertical movement, one for controlling horizontal movement and one for controlling English per player, as well as one dial for controlling ball speed and one dial for controlling the position of the line
>the serve button has been removed, instead the player whose turn it is can serve the ball by touching the line (which actually gives it a gameplay function in the table tennis game instead of just being a visual indicator for where the rules said you "were allowed" to go, like on the original Odyssey. It still serves as such an indicator here though, the paddles can still go wherever they want on the screen and players need to police each other to follow the rules)
>the game still does not keep score, but now it has plastic sliders on the console to make it easier to keep count
>as mentioned, hitting the top or bottom of the screen will now make the ball bounce off, which probably feels a bit weird with the entire English paddle thing that otherwise gives you complete control over where the ball goes
>there's also a second selectable game, hockey, where the line gets a hole in the middle and needs to be placed at the left side of the screen, while a second, similar line will appear on the right side. Hitting the ball with these will have the same effect as if that player's paddle had hit it

It all looks and feels very very awkward and clumsy, not to mention extremely primitive compared to Atari's Pong consoles that WERE out at the time. They hadn't quite yet zeroed in on exactly what made Pong a better game than Odyssey Table Tennis.

>is that a bad boxart? cause it makes me wanna research it and see what its about

average solid platform game from the looks of it. 2d platformer in a 3d environment, like Pandemonium, or the sidescroller levels in Crash Bandicoot. The catch is that since you are a spider, you can walk up on walls and ceilings, which makes some of the paths very trippy. Also you can get weapons like bombs, boomerangs, guns, poison cannons, which turn you into a half-robotic spider with a cannon arm and such. Your default weapon is just a melee attack, so having ranged attacks will help.


Boxart is actually very accurate in that regard.

I don't know how games were sold in Europe or Japan, but in the US at least a lot of games were sold behind the checkout counters of stores or in small, 2cm by 2cm images in catalogs. There's a bunch of games I remember seeing as a kid that I didn't know anything about but I remembered the cover. Even Toys R Us would often just have the game in a case and you asked for a copy in the front. this was as late as 2010 IIRC.

So that atmospheric piece with two tiny figures walking in a landscape with a windmill in the background? from far away behind a counter, or in a tiny catalog, people aren't seeing the little figures clearly. Just some vague buildings.

I used to read some graphic design textbooks. And I can tell you, a lot of /gd/ fags probably will say these look great.
This is because for years, graphic designers were always taught that "minimalism = good". Blank space? Good and great taste. Minimal typography? Good and great taste. So this was the trend used everywhere in the 70s and 80s. Picrel is an example of it done well. You can see the concept is extremely similar.
The problem is, this just taught a whole profession of faggots who stopped thinking critically, and instead just made blank covers, added typography and a basic image, then gave themselves a pat on the head and jerked to their work with other graphic designers over how "minimalistic" it is. They didn't even think for a second that this is boring and ugly, and hardly makes you excited for a video game.
Hence why everyone hates designers and thinks they are retarded.

>>9622221
>S-Video didn't even exist until after the NES was already on the market. A 1990 TV with S-Video would have possibly been even more than $500. It would be the top of the line.

The Super Nintendo has an official S-Video cable. When S-Video first rolled out for TV sets, they were pretty limited to TV's that were 27inch or bigger. 25inch TV's and smaller would not have S-video output back in 1991. Though in the later half of the 90's, there were smaller sets with S-video. Component wasn't even a thing until 1998 or 1999. The GameCube, PS2 and OG Xbox all had component connectors. The Dreamcast was a bit early for component, but has VGA and Svideo. Sadly the genesis did not have any s-video options, and on't RF or composite RCA connectors. The Saturn was the first Sega console with Svideo.

posts.sub: Let's talk about Silent Hill 1 and 2
posts.com: Recently played through both these games and enjoyed them. I feel like 2 has the best sound design and story of the two, while 1 has better enemies, gameplay, and levels. What do you think about these games? Do you know any interesting facts or stories about these games?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9623389
Silent Hill 1 is heavily entrenched in occult symbolism and esoteric lore. The basis of it's structure is that of alchemical transmutation. All of those key items you pick up in the final area aren't random--they represent key aspects that demonstrate your understanding and mastery of the occult ritual you had just underwent.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: They wanted the town in Silent Hill 1 look American, obviously, but the interiors are all tiny like in Japan. That's your fun fact for the day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9623389
Whenever I play them I always go back to the question of how to make resources work without an re style inventory slot limit and item box trip busywork, I don't think the SH games really succeed here, instead of having to consider resources for the entire game it just funnels your stockpiles into a handful of spongey lategame bosses which I don't think is all that engaging.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9623389
>What do you think about these games?

1 felt deeply unnerving as kid, I never completed it. When I revisited it cca 10 years ago I found it to be a very interesting adventure game but I hated how easy it was to get the wrong ending. Mechanically it's so-so, very inferior to RE games which is also probably why I don't find myself wanting to replay it much. Its more of an experience than a straight up video game. 9/10

I also played 2 around the same time about 10 years ago or so and getting the In Water ending on the first run made quite an impression. I liked the game a lot and its atmosphere appealed to me more than the occult stuff from 1. Mechanically it's more of the same. One of the best games ever made.

3 I didn't like much at all. Already on the first run it felt very short and I didn't appreciate how action heavy it was. Protagonist did nothing for me and some of the segments (haunted house) felt very cheesy. Probably the least favorite in the series.

4 has arguably the best premise, setup and jumpscare in the series but the execution is absolute dogshit. Worth playing once but I'm never replaying it in this life.

Homecoming - better than expected. It has a suprisingly good atmosphere and its an okay enough horror game - especially if you consider what the genre became later on. It's enjoyable if you can stand some clunk and aren't a SH autist purist.

Origins - same as the above, in a classic SH package. In general I have to say that I enjoyed both Origins and Homecoming more than 3 and 4.

SM - only played the gimped PS2 version. It felt like a very comfy adventure game but the chase sequence ruined it for me. Worth playing once.

Didn't play Downpour.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I remember tearing apart my xbox 360 and cleaning out shitloads of cat hair and fixing the RROD. Even the radioshack employee who sold the thermal paste smugly asked me if I was doing that. It worked for a few more years until the video card melted.
Modding the original xbox is a great experience, if only for putting a huge hard drive on it and custom firmware. That thing is a monument to modern media players.
The PS2 has physical locks that you can bypass. The PSP with pandora batteries as well. The whole modchipping scene is now popular with Switch consoles. Now a freemcboot card can be bought easily and do everything you want.
I’ve heard of DJs modding game boy colors to output MIDI and using them as chiptune effects. It’s a very niche genre but I think people here can at least appreciate sounds from original hardware.
The PortableWii scene is interesting. Very interesting. There’s a whole world here to explore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've done a bunch of mods. Here's a brief list:
Famicom composite (worthless*)
Mega drive 60Hz (worthless*)
Gameboy backlight/bivert (mediocre, lots of ghosting, angles are fucky)
GBA chink AGS-101 swap (great to look at, but holding a GBA isn't comfortable as an adult)
PS1 modchip (worthless*)
Dreamcast GD-emu, fan swap (great, although the fan swap needed some extra work)
N64 RGB mod (great)
Xbox 128mb swap (worthless, I wanted to play VC3 but there's no good way to get a lightgun working on it)
Switch joycon d-pad shell (inferior shiny plastic, but having a d-pad is too important. I use them in the grip anyway, so you barely notice it)

Softmods:
PS2 freeMCboot, HDD>SD adapter (great)
Xbox softmod (great)
Wii softmod (great)

All the worthless* are for mods that were superseded by MiSTer, at the time they were okay.

posts.name: Anonymous

Buy a soldering iron (ideally one with temp control), buy one of those little copper wire cleaning balls, buy some solder. You're done, now go try and solder shit to and from random old crap you have lying around until you get the idea.

Soldering is easy as shit. Soldering neatly? That's a different story, but you can get away with fairly ugly joints no problem, just give them a bit of a tug to check.

>>9616652
Is there any chance that you're using a microSDHC card with an old microSD to SD adapter? I have quite a few of these around the house and some of them simply refuse to work with the faster/newer microSDHC cards. Worst case scenario, you could consider using a small form factor USB drive, like proper tiny one that won't stick out of the PS2 and booting games through OPL straght from that. Them tiny USB sticks come in really large sizes (capacity-wise I mean) nowadays, they cost next to nothing and you really don't have to worry about read and write speeds, because the PS2 won't get faster than 1mb/s, which is still faster than using discs.

I've modded and repaired a ton of systems and games that were on their last legs. I do it to try to keep as much vidya from going into the trash bin.
I still feel really bad about mods that irreversibly change the OG hardware tho.
For example I found a Atari 2600 6 switcher and have been cleaning it this week. I now got it running, but a composite mod would be nice and easy to do...
But I would just feel conflicted about it since there is only so many left in the world, history, etc.
At the end of the day it's your stuff, do what you want. Some mods are pretty cool... but have some class.
If its broke and you don't want it- give or sell it to someone who is capable of fixing it.
Don't be the person that spray paints consoles gold and slaps leds on them, or guts a nes and puts a raspberry pi in it to show "how much of a quirky geek you are!" or the fuck ever.

>>9623382
>"Fair wage" is complete bullshit and inflames inflation and unemployment. No one can define it
Then let me give you an idea. Most ideas of "minimum wage" are based on trying to keep up with the rate of inflation relative to the arguably arbitrary number that MW started at many decades ago.

To be "fair", it should be tied not to inflation, but to the GDP and the national prosperity
as a whole. As the nation gets richer, everyone in it should get richer. So if we tie the minimum wage to per capita income, we get about $25/hr for 2020.

To be clear, that isn't the same as dividing total wealth by number of people, and then writing that as an hourly wage. If we did that the number would go way way up. The per capita income of the US is about $62,000/yr. But since only half those people are in the workforce (many are children, etc.), we double that, to get $124,000. With 2080 hours in a work year, that comes out to about $60/hr. If everyone were paid the same, that is what you might make. This doesn't take into account the open secret that the majority of the wealth of the 1% is hidden and squirreled away in offshore accounts and shell corporations.

If you don't want to tie it to the GDP of the nation, then it should be tied to profits of the employer. Every employee should get paid in a percentage, not a flat rate. Since Wal-Mart, Amazon and most other corporations are reporting record-breaking profits every year, their employees should also be seeing record-breaking earnings. If you want to claim they did not contribute or are not essential to these profits, why are they employed?

These threads that come up from time to time about how gaming was "so expensive" back in the day come from a gross oversimplification of economics. Yes, if you just plug numbers into an inflation calculator it makes it seem like only rich fucks could have ever owned a video game ever. "Dude, Street Fighter II cost $180 in today's money! herpderp!" But that's ignoring that if you were working a full time job in the 1990s you could afford to feed yourself and keep a roof over your head, sometimes even with only one bread winner in the household. Today you work a full time job and you're just barely scraping by, if that. The cost of an N64 and a few games look way different than the cost of a PS5 if you compare the larger contexts. Regardless of whether gaming was more "expensive" back then, it was way more AFFORDABLE.

There's a reason the 90s was so prosperous. Ordinary people were literally getting richer after the comparatively shitty 1980s. This is also why the crime rate plummeted. In the 1970s and 1980s you might get raped and mugged on the subway by two completely different people while your rapist is also getting mugged.

The only reason we think of the 80s as a high point is because in our gaming bubble things looked awesome because our 1990s was Japan's 1980s. People thought Japan was going to take over the world through sheer economic dominance. Die Hard's entire story takes place in a building called Nakatomi Plaza. They were having an economic boom and exporting amazing electronics. Then in the early 90s their economy crashed and America saw it's own boom, which in the video game sphere allowed for the continued upward trend since it was then still viable to produce high end equipment American yuppies could afford. The video game and larger computer market had the latitude to just keep growing in this atmosphere.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9616723
>it improves upon the original in every meaningful way
You are now forced to obtain the sword key as Jill, reducing exploration options.
The keys are now obtained in a set order, meaning that sequence breaking and seeing unique scenes is no longer possible.
Rebecca only appears with Richard, which was a hidden event in the original game.
When fighting against Yawn, in the original 3 events could occur dependent on the choices the player made throughout the game. You either have to get the antidote yourself, play a sequence as the partner character, or are carried by the partner character. Only the first event occurs in the remake due to the complete removal of all choices.
The true opening of the game is changed and made nonsensical. In the original, the player would be left in the main hall after the first encounter with any door to choose from. In the remake, all of the paths are locked or are immediate dead ends, with the only actual path being a linear straight line to get a crossbow, filled with constant tutorializing the original never had (in addition to the remake still having Barry say he'd be searching over there, which he isn't).
All optional rooms from the original are made mandatory with the exception of the aquarium office, but that contains the crest that unlocks the magnum so it is basically not optional.
Getting the crank is turned from a couple seconds of stair pushing to a walk down a straight forest path (which makes no sense as the reason they don't leave the mansion is because of the dogs, and dogs never spawn here). You go through two "puzzles" that essentially solve themselves with how braindead they are, and it concludes with the laughable first Lisa encounter, where she knocks you out and then does... nothing before fighting you when you wake up.
The Guardhouse is turned into a straight line with zero exploration despite that area being the most open to expansions given its size in the original concepts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616723
>>9616780
The process of getting anything done in Neptune's room is extended to the point of annoyance, turning a relatively short sequence into a several minutes long one of running around in a very dull and very empty environment, complete with a return trip if you want to use the V-Jolt. You also lose the box pushing path for seemingly no reason other than to force the player to use the other door for equally little reason.
The library in the mansion is reduced from 3 rooms, one hidden and one hosting a puzzle, complete with their own files and unique environments, into a more generic library to be a boss arena for a far easier Yawn boss fight. None of the elements of the original library are replicated.
The Yawn boss room is turned into an incredibly simple pushing puzzle where going through the grave is now mandatory, instead of being optional.
The hunters are less of a threat since the game adds shortcuts that reduces their presence in route planning immeasurably.
The caves are expanded but nothing interesting is added, just another box pushing puzzle.
The "lore" surrounding Lisa is the BOW equivalent of a Mary Sue, where she's incredibly special and important to every advancement Birkin made and is also partly immortal.
The caves not leading right into the lab results in several minutes of time wasting where the player runs through pretty much entirely empty hallways in a straight line back to the main hall.
The MO Disk Hunt only starting in the lab reduces any interesting exploration for the player, effectively making them not think about the future by removing any items that will be used in the future.
The lab puzzles are pretty much the same, just with extra steps, while the lab itself has zero expansions whatsoever beyond literal walking towards the end.
The game removes all past unlockables from RE1 and replaces them, meaning no original costumes, weapons, or modes. This means no Battle Game or Advanced Mode.
It sucks.

>>9623471
I prefer Gen 1 to Gen 2, but they both have their strengths.
Gen 1 is a simple, fun adventure. It puts obvious, structured challenges in front of you and gives you the tools to overcome them in the way you feel best.
Gen 2 is more about drinking in the atmosphere and the sensation of going on a journey. The locations are more detailed and distinct and there are more things to do. At the same time, the focus is drawn away from the core gameplay somewhat.
I tend to look for an experience more like Gen 1 but if Gen 2 is your favorite it's a fine choice.

>>9623539
Challenge shouldn't be a huge factor for anyone on this board. I seriously hope none of us are bad enough at the series to be stumped at any point by any of the mainline games.
Gen 1 has up to three potentially difficult fights in it. Brock, Misty, and the Elite Four + Champion. These are the only points in the game a player who has a vague idea what they are doing could lose to.
Lets just say for arguments sake that Gen 2 has zero fights that can be lost.
That means that Gen 1 has one hour of real gameplay and Gen 2 has zero hours. The rest is different variations of pressing A.
That is only a difference of sixty minutes. It isn't that big a change in the long run.
Gen 2 makes up for that difference by filling its world with new places to see and things to do. Not everyone will like that trade but it isn't unreasonable.

Again, I agree with you that Gen 1 is better. But Gen 2 is a perfectly fine game on its own merits and a reasonable follow-up to the original.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9623503
A good idea, executed pretty badly.

The plot is neat, works kinda like an "Episode 0" of the show (until it was soft-retconned in the show's final season).

The controls are ass. Since this was before analog controls became staple you're forced to maneuver 3D space with the dpad, via tank controls. And the camera is unwieldy as its always trying to stay behind Bob to keep whatever he needs to aim at front-and-center on screen.

They gave Bob a couple of guns to blast enemies with, despite it was never really part of his character to wield heavy weaponry. You use Glitch mainly to seal Tears throughout each level, which are a pain in the ass to both fine and seal.

Oh, and not only is it a 3D shoot-em-up but its also a 3D platformer at times, and very bad at it. Bob's Zipboard is finicky as fuck to do jumps with.

You have to complete every stage perfectly (yes you can fail them) to get the game's best ending.

But hey, at least the intro is nice:
https://streamable.com/lyngec

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Rocky and Bullwinkle on NES is a fuckin' joke. The graphics are absolute shit. The sprites look like they were drawn by a three-year-old, and the animation is so choppy it makes me wanna puke. The audio is worse. The music is so repetitive and annoying, it's like someone just mashed a bunch of random notes together and called it a day. I'm sure the developers thought it was 'cute' or 'clever', but it's just fuckin' terrible.

The gameplay is just as bad. The controls are sluggish and unresponsive, like trying to drive a car with a broken transmission. The hit detection is a disaster, too. You'll jump into enemies and take damage for no fuckin' reason at all. And the levels? Don't even get me started. They're filled with cheap traps and enemies that are placed just out of reach, forcing you to take damage or miss a jump.

All in all, Rocky and Bullwinkle on NES is one of the worst games ever made. The graphics, audio, and gameplay are all so abysmal, it's a fuckin' insult to the gaming industry. If you want a good old-school game, look elsewhere.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I think UG1-THAW had a constant progression of polish. UG1 opened up the game from the classic arcade play, but I think they didn't get a clear sense of direction until UG2. American Wasteland perfected not only the skating, but also made the off board movement as bearable as it could possibly get. The themes of American Wasteland were cringe in retrospect (but it came out during peak 2000s MTV edge so it didn't feel that way on release if you were younger.) The loading halls was pretty innovative and felt seamless at the time as well. I don't think any of them were bad and they all had their place, but I think THAW was the final product for sure. Also, Idk what >>9620360 is talking about when it comes to THPS3. I think the foundry was just as iconic of a intro level as the other two games had. I actually prefer it over the hanger, and even though THPS3 is my favorite out of them all, I think Warehouse is the most iconic of intro levels ofc.

posts.com:
They're both significantly better than THUG

THPS4 fails as a Tony Hawk game by not being fun to play a second time. You can't execute challenges on demand; you have to first talk to the person. The combat in Morrowind is definitely 100% functional...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9614920
There's really no need to fix the combat.

You see; Morrowind makes you specialize. The way old table top games do like DnD.

If you didn't choose magic options in your character creation? GUESS WHAT? You're gonna dice roll on spells for a LONG time until you level it up or spend the gold for training which you CAN do. Can go total blade sword or something easily.

But if you pick agility as a main attribute and (Insert weapon skill) as one of your primaries from the get go. Then GUESS WHAT; You'll HIT WITH YOUR WEAPON A LOT MORE OFTEN! Could argue it even adds some realism to the game like imagine a kid trying to use a sword for the first time... he'd SUCK AT IT>

It's that simple. Morrowind doesn't hold your hand but there are a gazillion guides out there that can help you achieve whatever desired effect/character you want. Hell if playing on PC or xbox there are even some glitches or console commands you can use to make damn sure you never miss again. It's a little cheaty but if missing swings filters you so hard well there's always oblivion and skyrim... The watered down versions of elder scrolls that came later. Oblivion had some potential in areas but idk maybe it was rushed in development or something. The vanilla game is so fucking boring. The DLC is... not bad.

I didn't hate Skyrim; I just wasn't over satisfied with it. I play through it sometimes but if I had to choose one of them to be stuck with; it's morrowind every time.
It's got insane depth to it, a bad ass main story line. Excellent DLC. And the most memorable moments and characters/missions.

good:

needs improvement:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For me personally: Ape Escape, Jumping Flash 1 and 2, and Klonoa: Door to Phantomile are all extremely aesthetically pleasing and well thought out. I extend aesthetic to include the way the game presents through audio as well, all those games have such nice color choices, character design and environments alongside music that fits impeccably to the environments.
Klonoa especially has some of my favorite enemy designs ever. There's thid part in the forest world, where you have to walk a full U-Turn path that encircles a massive wooden gear - the first time you pass it, the enemies (iirc) are flying blue Moos - the second pass, once the gear is in motion, instead contains two very alien looking enemies that appear nowhere else in the game. I never knew why they did that when it seemed so arbitrary, but my instincts are they created something cool, wanted it in the game, and put them in just to do it, just for visual variety and to just kinda be noticed. >it could be possible to reproduce the CMOS variant used in the Genesis 2 although not the NMOS VDP in the Model 1
Why's that? I don't know anything about chip production.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9599906
70s-80s chips were often NMOS logic. This is when all the transistors in the chip are n-doped. It has the disadvantage of using a lot of power and getting hot as it forces every transistor in the chip to draw current even when idling, and it also produces a lot of signal line noise and can have glitchy behavior due to how the logic works.

All modern chips (anything designed in the last 30+ years) are CMOS logic, which is a mix of p and n-doped transistors. It is much more efficient and cooler running as idling transistors do not use any power and it's free of signal line noise and glitches. However it was not widely used for years as it was more complex to manufacture and early CMOS chips were very slow (solved when they found they could just thin the metallization layer). CMOS chips are less forgiving of sloppy system design as they can be damaged by a bus conflict as that will drive the signal lines on the chip high, while NMOS signal lines would go low.

It'll be interesting with the Mega Drive, because no other console went through so many makeovers, revisions and restylings, so it'll be amazing to have one that'd essentially be a CDX, but even smaller, can output the crispest video and audio, and sips power. IIRC Mega Drive chips were all off the shelf so some beautiful autist is definitely whittling away at this. Exciting times in this sector of retro development, OP! Get psyched. :)

>>9600147
There's a capacitor on the GND and CHR/RD pins of the cartridge slot. That seems to have fixed the issue with Rambo; apparently some problem with corrupted CHR data. A resistor pack links the VRAM with one of the TTLs (?) and there's resistors/caps attached to the power rails in three different places. They're tied to ground on the other end. Maybe these were put there to improve power line filtering.

if you look at the game files to see how it prioritizes alien missions it's actually quite cute and you can see how the game designers planned everything out. different alien species have different probabilities of doing a particular mission, and different regions get different mission probabilities.

>Europe gets a lot of infiltration missions because it's a major X-COM funding area
>but alien bases are rare there because aliens prefer to put those in more sparsely populated areas
>Southeast Asia gets a lot of abduction missions due to its huge population density
and so forth

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616097
It's simple, really: Final Fantasy IV exists in a bizarro vacuum were there are no real "bad" versions of the game. The Super Famicom release? One of the earliest original versions that still holds up well. The PlayStation port? Surprisingly the best out of all the PlayStation conversions, they somehow really knocked the wait times way out of the park compared to the rest. The DS remake? Fixed handheld-constraint issues that plagued 3D Final Fantasy III. The PSP compilation? The most "complete" package and best localization overall, worst anyone can say is it don't look as good as previous PSP remakes. Even the censored/easy Super Nintendo release is still enjoyable. The only versions I'd say are outright bad are the cheap Wonderswan version -which goes to show just how bizarro-world this game really is- and the initial revision of the GBA version based on it. And maybe pixel remaster for braindead-regressing to a worse translation and casualizing a few aspects, but that's PR for you.
In short, Final Fantasy IV simply has more good options to choose from.

>>9619778
PSP expanded a few parts to fit more in line with TAY, like changing "Yang's Wife" to "Sheila" (which is a Japanese change too). Since that wasn't the goal of Pixel Remaster, they took the path of least resistance and based it on the more compatible GBA version, mildly tweaking a few parts. Similar reason why PSP was also a moderately tweaked GBA script instead of a heavily tweaked DS one - it requires less fuddling to fit in with the 2D versions. For that matter, most parts that PSP shared with DS is a consequence of TAY text being based on the at-the-time more recent DS script.
>The 2D version hasn't had a full new translation since PSX
It's maybe slightly less reworked than Final Fantasy VI on GBA, but I doubt you want to debate that it hasn't had a full new translation since SNES.

>>9616268

I like this approach, play THE game. You're already taking something that was good enough
to be relevent when it came out for a generation of players
and skipping it to play a cleaned up version far fewer people will ever play.

Also, PSP and DS retranslations are shit.

The reason JRPGs have lost their charm is because the industry is trying to do a one to one translation of Japanese.

It started around the time of FFX where they done voice acting. As the Japanese companies
put more effort into Western translations they took more control of the process.

So instead of some rando translating games in a way he thought would make sense, as even an amateur writer would

New translations are trying to be accurate and because of this they're incredibly bland.

Example of this would be Metal Gear Solid 1,
In the Japanese version May Ling gives Snake these fortune cookie parables which only make sense in Japanese.

For the Western release the translator wisely decided to go with war quotes. You still get Snakes puzzlement at some of them included,
but overall it was better.

Kojima fired that translator later for their changes. Very few people will think the writing improved after MGS1. It's because of the translation.

Play remaster versions of JRPGs and watch all the personality of the 90s
get drained out of the games.

Or play what made them popular here in the first place,

The PSX version of FF4 has a decent translation, as does 6 because it was done similiarly to how the
greatest games like 7, 8, and 9 were localised.

So I'd go with that or the original, but avoid anything more recent.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9621971
The game is from that window in time in which cramming up a bunch of different gameplay styles was considered a selling point, instead of a simple but inevitable indication of the developers not having spent enough time polishing each one.

It's a really fun game once you get it, but the quality and entertainment value is all over the place. There's levels like the Snake Pit that have a great concept but once you've played them a couple times they're just a boring slog in your way to parts of the game that are actually enjoyable. Others like Clinger Winger are mostly there to fuck with the player and, again, remain as a boring formality once you understand how they work. And then there's shit like Volkmire's Inferno, which is just a half-assed version of Turbo Tunnel without the fun and WITH mandatory memorization to add insult to injury.

To be fair, it's amazing they actually managed 3-4 playstyles that are actually pretty damn well implemented, if not "polished" as such.

It's a good game but I would (charitably) include it in the top 25 at most; the NES has a great library with much better designed and executed games.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9622004
The difference is, the west used to have the "get good" mentality, even as a general player base. The harder the game was = the better it was seen (as long as it didn't fall into complete BS category), magazines used to have a "longetivity/challenge" rating. This is also proven by countless ads praising a game's difficulty.

Meanwhile there wasn't really such a mentality in Japan outside of the most hardcore players like SHMUP enthusiasts, instead the general player base kept complaining that the RPGs were too hard.

Now this mentality has been lost for a long time, to the point people even convince themselves that any and all difficulty (especially different balances depending on regions) was "bad design on purpose to fuck with rentals" so they can feel better about cheating or dismissing the game instead of making the intended effort to get good. We're all Japanese now.

The "memorization" argument is thrown around often enough about Battletoads, but ironically it's often about the Turbo Tunnel level, which doesn't really require it as such: you'll "get" it once you've had a bunch of goes at it, but modern gamers do tend to blur the line between requirements of experience vs full blown memorization. It feels better to claim a game is "poorly designed" than to admit you can only deal with challenges if they are not actually challenging.

Volkmire's Inferno does involve memorization though, and some of the later regular levels are tough unless you learn a couple tricks about where to position yourself on the screen in certain situations.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9622215
I like the game well enough, but you are claiming yourself it isn't really enjoyable until you've put in the work, which is an odd thing to say if you're actually defending it.

The "filtered" argument's most obvious flaw is that there's plenty challenging games that are fun to play from the moment you pick them up, in opposition to others that never manage to be rewarding or play as more than a chore. People around /vr/ seem to often mistake an actual worthwhile and fun experience with the simple satisfaction of overcoming a challenge; that's real enough, but certainly not the same thing. Challenge by itself isn't necessarily fun, but there IS such thing as fun challenges. There must be additional factors that make the latter equation possible.

All that said, I do think Battletoads is fun enough even when you're bad at it; but there's plenty moments in the game that clearly sink the fun factor and drag down the experience for novice and even intermediate players.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622094
>Now this mentality has been lost for a long time, to the point people even convince themselves that any and all difficulty (especially different balances depending on regions) was "bad design on purpose to fuck with rentals"
I don't think many people claim that was the only factor at all, and it certainly wasn't all bad design, but publishers had a greater interest if the game couldn't be beat quickly. If you could see all the game had to offer within the span of a quick rental, would you then wanna rent it again or outright buy it?
If the game hooked the player, but it also demands enough effort that they want to go buy it, then that's the best case possible for a publisher, this doesn't mean that people didn't ever seek a challenge or that it wasn't ever a marketing point, just that devs and publishers had a vested economical interest in making sure it wasn't too quick in easy. If anything, this means that good devs and publishers were actually meeting half way with their customers.

Unless, of course, part of the difficulty was made to serve the rental market, which of course doesn't exist in Japan.

The game was designed to be playable using 33.6k models that shipped with European consoles. You'll be fine over dialup.

I think PSO is a lot of fun in solo mode, although it'll obviously be more difficult and you'll be missing out on the fun of co-op. It can feel very zen by yourself though, and it's definitely a game I enjoy replaying.

I'm a Dreamcastfag but honestly at this point if you're interested in playing PSO it will be better to check out one of the versions that has the Episode 2 content. The base game (Episode 1) has four zones. Each zone has two levels, plus a boss area at the end of the second level. Episode 2 adds like six or seven new zones, so it's a shitload more content. The Dreamcast version (both the original, and ver2) are both just Episode 1. The X-Box, Gamecube, and PC versions all have Episodes 1 and 2.

Also, don't forget to feed your mag.

posts.com:
just tried it myself starting last week, playing on my gdemu Dreamcast. I was of the right age to have played it in its time but just never got a Dreamcast.

it's a bit of a repetitive snooze, but I'm ambivalent about it rather than negative. the combat feels more immediate than most MMOs because continuing a combo is timing-based. death results in penalties per the trends of its time, you lose all your carried money and as far as I can tell a random selection of your carried items--if you drop your weapon, especially at the beginning, this is a big fuck in your ass. environments are tunnels and spreads, reminding me a lot of pre-World monster hunter, except less visually distinctive so you're absolutely gonna get your ass lost.

despite that visually it's joyful like every Sega game that generation, very comfy. the music is also very nice, so atmospherically altogether it's a great time. maybe it's just my race/class combo but the PC walk cycles look a bit retarded, and I wish there was a faster way to get around in the maps than their doofy leisurely jog.

this is a summation based on a blind about 4 hours of single-player so take it with the grain of salt that suggests. it's been fun to muck around in so far but I don't feel a great compulsion to keep playing it. coming into the dragon fight completely underprepared but somehow coming out successful was hype though, I admit.

Played the demo that came with Official UK PSM. Utterly blown away, I immediately bought the game the second I saw it on a shelf.

Zero regrets, I played through the whole thing three times over, back to back.

The level of presentation and cinematography in MGS was in a league of its own at the time. It seriously stood out, and the fact that it was done with the in-game engine showed just what a collosal waste of time all of those pre-rendered videos we'd become used to had been.

The actual gameplay is pretty basic , but my god, what a polished experience the game was for 1998. There was nothing else on that level back then.

'Style over substance' could be a valid criticism, but stealth as a core gameplay mechanic was so rare to see back then that even MGS' simple implementation of it was perfectly fresh.

posts.com: I noticed that mgs appealed to people that weren't typically into traditional games though not the way you'd think it being a movie game, more in it being a quasi dad game. I remember my brothers playing a few of the big 3rd and 4th gen platformers like super mario bros and dkc but mainly the games I remember them being into were driving, sports, a couple old flight sims, a couple fighting games, basically games where you were doing a recognizable activity instead of running through an abstract gauntlet. if mgs were a game where you just went room to room killing things rapid fire, boss fight, repeat my brothers would have had zero interest. however the slow adventure game like pacing, the optional codec calls, all the tech gimmicks and ways you could fuck with guards, this was very cool to them. Even my dad perked up once when he oversaw us messing around with a cardboard box. my brothers hated raiden in 2 but sticking up guards was something they could do for hours.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9618629
Laugh all you want at the melodrama and Kojimaisms but at the time, there had never been any mainstream game that excelled to that extent in terms of writing and voice acting and gameplay. FFVII had a great story and everyone loved the characters but there was a certain cartoonishness to it and everything was rendered purely in text on in pre-rendered cutscenes where no one spoke. Resident Evil was very cinematic but the "acting" was cheesy and amateurish. The Characters in MGS were the first, for a lot of people, where you felt like there was a genuine performance behind it, with actual voice acting like you'd find in an animated film and not just some guy reading off a cue card. It felt like an important threshold had been crossed. It was a benchmark for quality.

And it was also a good game that didn't play like anything else. Stealth was an underutilized mechanic so a game based around it seemed fresh and unique. It had memorable bosses, tons of cool gadgets, challenging but fair difficulty...it was just mild-blowing. Now I find it a little slow and limited but still very playable. At the time, I'd never seen anything like the total package this game offered. Zoomers will never understand the feel of fighting Psycho Mantis for the first time, being freaked out y him reading your memory card and having to figure out his gimmick. That kind of shit was unprecedented.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622196
Street Racer plays largely on a perfectly level ground plane save for the geometry used for the obstacles; they did an ok job of upgrading the original game but it's still essentially a souped up 16-bit style racer and for all intents and purposes the same gameplay could still work on the mode-7 implementation.

Mario Kart has its crude-ish implementation of pre-rendered sprite characters, but the game is true 3D in terms of environments (sloping and overlapping terrain to begin with). And after all, most if not all other 5th gen "full 3D" racers still use sprites for the vehicle wheels for example, and it's not as if the "true" 3D geometry of the characters is actually reactive in terms of physics. MK64 and games like CTR use a similar collision model regardless of how the elements are visually implemented.

Long windedness aside, I'm not arguing that comparing Street Racer to other less primitive battle racing games is perfectly valid; it's just a peculiar choice for a "Better than MK64" claim given there's plenty other more directly comparable competitors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616583
Peter Molyneux's last masterpiece before turning into the pathological liar we all know today. It's a weird mixture of management sim, real-time strategy and god game with light rpg elements. The idea is that in a Diablo or a Wizardry or any classic rpg dungeon crawler you play as a hero wandering into a dungeon that's populated with hundreds of different monsters. In Dungeon Keeper you're running the dungeon, building tunnels and different rooms in order to attract more and more vile monsters and then you have to keep them happy, train them up, mine for gold in order to keep them paid and so on. Then occasionally you'll end up tunneling into either another dungeon or you'll be invaded by a group of heroes at which point it becomes something closer to an rts.

Really great and unique. God-tier atmosphere. Good sequel that had a lot of UI and common sense improvements but the atmosphere just wasn't there in the same way. Still an okay follow-up though. In both games the AI's a bit shit but that's forgivable considering it was the late 90s. Only real problem is that there hasn't been a real, true follow-up since DK2. There was a mobile game that was riddled with microtransactions about a decade ago but that's it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9619436
Unironically learn basics of Photoshop from some online tutorials or have someone else do it for you if you can't find quality scans online. I've started writing a post on how to go about it earlier today, but in the end went "fuck it" once I've realized it would take ages to explain in writing, whereas if we'd meet IRL I could probably teach you in like thirty minutes. So yeah anon, download Photoshop, watch some tutorials, fuck around with it. It'll come in handy in life, won't be wasted time. Basic pointers are to use CMYK, start with a large project file (you lose quality when you "zoom in", so it's better to go large initially and then scale down on the image right before sending it to print), use the proper dimensions (can easily find these online) for boxes/labels and whenever you can copy shit from other high quality scans / projects. Say if someone already made a high quality "Nintendo Seal of Quality" vector, just copy that instead of retracing the whole thing on your own, no need to reinvent the wheel.

>>9620770
They have been mentioned already, but it's basically:
>Arcade games being developed as pocket drainers with unreal difficulty spikes so people used more and more coins.
>Memory capacity didn't allow for long games so there was some padding achieved with the difficulty, with RPGs coming to mind with the jump into home consoles.
>A community built around solving puzzles and riddles, constantly having a back and forth with the developers for clues or ideas. The Wizardry games in the west and other PC ones, for example.
>Third party groups (translators, coders to move games across platforms, etc.) being massives dicks for no reason. Suffice to say, the retards at Working Designs have a place reserved in hell for this.
>Games were mostly designed as being a challenge, and not a time sinker to wind down. You had adventure games and sims and that, but the business model was different from the current one that favors a casual approach.

>>9620770
Magazines used to have a "challenge" rating, or if not, a "longetivity" rating which was greatly influenced by the game's difficulty.

Ads often praised a game's difficulty.

All this just shows that players (at least in the west, Japan was different) were seeking the challenge. It wasn't just "devs/publishers fucking with the players because rentals or X-Y other reason that make me feel better today".

Parents when choosing to buy a game, for the same price, will choose a game the kid will come back to again and again before being done with it. And as a player, easy games that were beaten would often be dismissed for a replay over a game not yet beaten, and beating some games was seen as a real achievement, not something you're entitled to because you bought the game, like today.

This mentality has completely changed now to the point people can't even imagine it ever being different. It started changing with the player base growing bigger and bigger and games shifting more towards "experiences" and "stories".

For some, games like those not constantly holding the player's hand is all they want, but there's those who seek out more.

Older games do also have some currency with some of the kids, as you'll see some here and there checking out an old classic to see what it's like with the understanding that it's different. Sometimes they're very pleasantly surprised at what the older game does differently, that they like it much better than how most of the modern counterparts do it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9620770
A bunch of varying reasons. To add substance to a game without increasing the amount of data taken up on the cartridge/disc. Transitioning from arcades where more difficulty meant more money for the owners of the cabinet which meant more sales. Developer difficulty that naturally happens when a developer plays their own game thousands of times, they get good at it, so their perception of the difficulty becomes skewed. People had far fewer games back then, so games weren't one and done like they are now, they had to be challenging because that was one of the handful of games you were going to buy for the whole year. Also the rental market, if it could be beaten in a weekend, people would rent it once and then have less reason to actually buy the game or rent it again. Also gaming was more niche and was more likely to be a hobby for nerds, so they would want the extra difficulty.

Those are pretty much all the main reasons old games were way harder.

It wasn't the primary factor, but it certainly wasn't miniscule either, there's lots of games where the dev was just cheap and did a shoddy job, and it was rationalized with "The game will last longer." or the publisher outright wanted to make sure that a kid couldn't beat it over a weekend, so they had to rent it more than once.

Sometimes it was just scatterbrained, Fester's Quest is tough as nails, and the devs weren't really thinking about how brutal it was until testers complained, then they decided to use it as a marketing point, that the game didn't pull any punches. One of the devs said that they realized late in development that the game should probably have had a password system, but that there was no time left.

Game Freak was a company that caught lightning in a bottle and had no idea how to handle it.
After essentially giving control to Nintendo (via the formation of The Pokemon Company) Game Freak changed from an independent gaming company to a branch of a brand management company.
A Japanese brand management company.
The Japs will almost always choose the status quo over progression, especially in larger companies.
Pokemon, as a product, is produced by THREE Jap companies (Game Freak, Nintendo, Creatures) which need the approval of a FOURTH jointly-owned (The Pokemon Co., by all three of the above) Jap company. This is before any external companies which could produce associated physical products are thrown into the mix.
Pokemon is locked into a bureaucratic quagmire (giggity). The stakeholders don't give a shit about making the games better. Their only measure of success is "not failure."

Scarlet&Violet's open world is an illusion.

"mainline" is just the English term for "Pocket Monsters", which got introduced once the English marketers got fed marketing material that differentiated between Pocket Monsters and Pokemon and had to deal with the fact that they were both just "Pokemon" in the west. So "Pocket Monsters" got translated as "mainline Pokemon" with no real explanation of what that was supposed to mean.

>are they any good.
Eh. Their main appeal is graphics/presentation and even those aren't spectacular. They also feel slow. They're worth trying out if you like how Gen 3 plays in particular and like double battles. But more like a curiosity at this point.

>. first you are like they never did it but then admit the existence of Colosseum/Gale of Darkness so what now?

Colosseum/GoD are barely full Pokemon games. There's a story campaign, but no gym challenge(there are bosses and stadiums, but not as many as in even the handhelds) almost no wild Pokemon except a patch in GoD, no extra world features. They're "a bit more intricate" in so much as they have an actual story mode where the stadium games had none, but not as much as doing the handheld games in 3D.
